g.text: Compiling C for a GNU Linux 0S
It's simply the process of converting some source
code into low-level machine code for a specific
processor architecture. It's a multi-stage process
that involves multiple tools to create a final
It expands macros and include files in the source
The -E option preprocess only; do not compile,
macros and code in the source.i file.
The source code is translated/compiled into
Assembly language is the processor instructions
for a specific architecture like MIPS, ARM, x86,
The -S option compile only; do not assemble or
The source.s file contains the assembly code
Assembly code is compiled into an object file
with machine code for a specific processor
The -c option compile and assemble, but do
Link object code together into a single object
file. Compiled objects will contain references
to functions or data that exists inside other
objects. it links symbols from other objects and
external libraries together to create single object
A symbol is simply a reference to a component in
a object file like or . A
symbol is eventually resolved to an address where
that component is located in memory.
If the executable uses function from some
creates references in the executable to
those symbols. When the binary is loaded
into memory and become a process the
symbols for those external libraries are
resolved by the dynamic linker or loader.
it means that the compiled executable
doesn't contain the actual code for those
functions that exist in shared libraries.
With static linking, all the symbols are
resolved at compile time and they are
compile into the final object file. So a
statically linked file contains all of the
code it needs to execute. So as you
maybe guessed it, a statically linked
file has a much bigger size than a
dynamically linked one. To create a
statically linked file you need to use
The GCC compiler will create 3 types of object
Relocatable: Non-executable file that needs to
Executable: It simply a binary that can be
A shared object: It's just a shared library. it's
not executable and designed to reside on the
target system, so the dynamic linker can link
into it when executable files on the system
On Linux, an object file is a form of ELF
The GCC compiler invokes the 4 stages that we
talked earlier so you don't need to do it
The file will be dynamically linked by default. We
talk about objects earlier and how they were linked
together into a single file. But you may be
wondering why I don't see the object file in the
directory where you compiled your program. It
simply because gdb deleted them but you have
an option to keep the objects. The
do not delete the intermediate files (.i .s .o).
Let's consider this code that simply print hello
world as output and include the library stdio.h
The file name of the code is source.c and the
binary name will be file. Let's examine this binary
after compiling it with the command:
In this case my filename is file
Compiling C for a GNU Linux 0S (1)
So first of all you can see ELF which means that it's an executable and linkable format and that the binary is for a
64-bit processor. LSB means Least Significant Byte. it means that the binary is in little endian.
The other possibility would be MSB for the most significant byte. It means that the binary is in Big Endian. Then
there is PIE executable. PIE stands for (Position Independent Executable). The equivalent on Windows is DEP
(Data Execution Prevention). It's a binary security that makes all of its dependencies loaded into random
locations within virtual memory each time the application is executed. Then the x86-64 is simply the processor
type. version 1 (SYSV) means that it's System V ABI version. Then it says that the binary is dynamically linked
and that it has references to symbols in some shared libraries. Then /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 is the interpreter
that my system will look for in the target system. The interpreter is the linker and loader so if the interpreter
doesn't exist you will have errors during the application execution. Then there is the Build ID in sha1. Then it says
that it's for GNU Linux and gives the version of it. Then it says that it's not stripped so the binary has a lot of
symbols which can help during debugging.
To have a lot of information about the binary we can use also the tool . We can use the option to
Start of program headers: 64 (bytes into file)
Start of section headers: 14144 (bytes into file)
We can also do to display the shared libraries that the binary needs in
If this library isn't loaded into memory the program won't be able to run. Also in order to run it needs to find the
interpreter. We can see the interpreter now.
So the interpreter simply defined which library should be used to load the binary into memory.
Now let's examine the temporary files during compilation. To keep it you need to use the option.
The source.i isn't really interesting, it's just the source code with al macros expanded etc. but let's examine
the assembly file. I just do a .
So as you can see there is in the data section our string
and in the main function, it calls the function printf. So the
object file doesn't have the actual code for the printf but calls it.
When it calls it's a reference to where it's actually
linked. So the call will be linked by the dynamic linker. We will
talk about that more in depth when we will talk about
the Procedure Linkage Table and the Global Offset Table (PLT
and GOT) in the next documentation.
As you can see it's a relocatable file, it means that it can't be
executed. It's imply an object file.
Ok now examine the statically linked version of this binary. I do
Since the binary contains all of the code it needs, as you can see
the static binary is 50x bigger than the dynamically linked one. If
you try to do a in the
static binary it will show nothing because it doesn't need any
library in order to run and it doesn't need an interpreter either.
